awd_titl_txt: Correlated Random Processes in Physical and Radar Meteorology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award allows for research on several intertwined issues related to radar meteorology, cloud physics, and the transfer of radiation through the atmosphere.  The specific research tasks within the proposal will answer questions regarding why some raindrops do not fall at their terminal velocities, how radiation travels through layered dust, and how supercooled water freezes.  These topics have a wide range of application, from improving radar estimates of rainfall to impacting materials sciences.  The research will include international collaborators and provide educational and training opportunities for students.  

The researcher will be studying the presence and impact of correlated fluctuations in cloud and precipitation physics, radar meteorology, and radiative transfer.  Theoretical studies, computer simulations, and field and laboratory data analysis will be conducted to answer questions related to five main research topics:  deviations of falling raindrops from their expected terminal speed, radiative transfer through a vertically stratified medium, coherence in radar backscatter using high resolution and short pulse data, temporal and spatial correlations of precipitation and their dependence on scale, and the effects of pressure fluctuations on the nucleation and freezing of supercooled water droplets.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Cloud properties such as reflection of incident light or propensity to drizzle or rain, depend on the distribution of droplet spatial positions and on the distribution of sizes.  The positioning, although seemingly random, when examined closely, has an element of order or ``texture’’ superimposed on randomness.  It is this type of texture that the word ``correlated’’ in the title of this award indicates. This project was focused on various types of such textures in space and time and their influence on cloud physical and optical properties as well as on the onset and structure of precipitation. To that end, scientific outcomes of the project are detailed in over 20 peer-reviewed journal articles and the main findings broadly fit in the following categories, listed below.

  • Development of mathematical methods and models for analysis of experimental data on cloud droplet and raindrop positions and arrivals, respectively.  An example: analysis of data from the Holographic Detector for Clouds (HOLODEC), flown in stratocumulus clouds to attempt detection of droplet clustering in turbulence.
  • Examination of observations on the optical properties of clouds, including a discovery of new phenomena such as oriented ice crystals in clouds reflecting light all the way to deep space.
  • Development of general and robust methods of data analysis to disentangle signals from noise in a distribution-independent manner, merely by ranking the data.
  • A method was developed to extract more of the information contained in the time series of drop counts in rain which can be used in weather radar-rainfall rate validations studies.

The award heled us to contribute to next generation of scientists with experience in atmospheric physics research by educating several physics majors and graduate students.
